loans.name: Mashibei

texts.en:
Mashibei is 54 years old, married to James, and they are blessed with four children: they are thirty one years old, twenty nine years old, twenty two years old, and fourteen years years old. She has been running her livestock business for the past eleven years. She earns a monthly income of about KES 14,000 which she uses to take care of her family.

She has been loaned KES 30,000 by KADET Ltd. This is her second loan from KADET. She intends to use the entire loan to purchase more livestock.

She plans to use the profit from her business to buy food for her family. In the future, she hopes to start a dairy farm.

loans.use: to purchase more livestock to rear and sell later on at a profit.

loans.name: Ritah's Group

texts.en:
Ritah is 21 years old and lives in the town of Nansana in the Kampala central region of Uganda. She is single and has no children. Ritah has a business selling food like matooke (steamed plantain), which she has run two years.
To help expand her business, Ritah has requested a loan of 400,000 Ugandan Shillings from Kiva partner, BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more food for resale. With the help of her loan from BRAC, Ritah hopes to generate greater profits and pay school fees for herself and for her young brother. In the future, she hopes to open up a hardware shop.
Ritah is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by helping her improve her business, which has, in turn, helped her pay her school fees.

loans.use: to purchase more food for resale.

loans.name: Pera Group

texts.en: Marykyori is his late 20s and single. He has been running a business growing and selling fresh vegetables for three years.   He works from 6am to 4pm daily and is able to make a fair monthly profit. This will be his second loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. He used the previous loan to extend his garden and grow more vegetables to sell. He has paid back his loan successfully. He wants a loan to buy seeds, fertilizer and pesticides for his vegetable garden. So he can grow more vegetables to sell. He will share this loan with his loan group "Pera" which has a total of 18 members, who will hold each other accountable in paying back their loans.

loans.use: To buy seeds, fertilizer and pesticides for the vegetable garden.

loans.name: Diorenda

texts.en: Diorenda is 41 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with 9 children. Diorenda has a retail shop that sells fish like sardines and milk fish. She has had this business for three years. She has requested a loan for PHP 4,000 to buy fish to sell. Diorenda is a new member of HSPFI. In the future, she hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy fish to sell

loans.name: Suha

texts.en:
Suha is a 49-year-old mother of four daughters and six sons. Two of her sons are not able of taking care of their families as they are outside Palestine. Suha and her husband take care of her two sons' families. Their two sons are unable to care for their families at this time not because they are not good husbands, but due to factors related to the political situation in Palestine. Suha and the family have a grocery store which is the only source of income for the entire family. 

Suha took out a loan from FATEN to pay for a variety of grocery items in order to attract more customers and have a better income to support such a big family.

Suha is a conservative woman therefore her son is photographed instead of her.

loans.use: to purchase a large variety of grocery items.

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 36-year-old married man from Lebanon. He lives with his wife and six children; five of them are still attending school. He has been working as a fisherman for more than 15 years. He owns a fishing boat. He works hard during the summer season to make a good profit since his sales increase during this season. 

Today, he is requesting to borrow $1200 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l to purchase required fishing equipment and supplies. He will also perform much needed repairs on his fishing boat. These modifications will facilitate his fishing operation and make it more secure especially in rough weather. In the future, he would like to purchase another boat.

loans.use: to purchase required fishing equipment and supplies and perform much needed repairs on his fishing boat.

loans.name: Hong

texts.en: Mrs. Hong is a 36-year-old farmer and mother who lives in the province of Kompong Cham. She was blessed with four children, most of whom attend public school. Her husband, Sorm, is 39 and works in the farming business. Mrs. Hong inherited the farmland from her grandmother and she and her husband grow different kinds of crops on it. They earn an average of $5 each day to help pay for the family's expenses. Rainy season is a good season for planting crops but Mrs. Hong doesn't have enough savings to do so. Therefore, Mrs. Hong would like a loan from Kiva as an advance for planting sugar cane.

loans.use: to plant sugar cane.

loans.name: Thelma

texts.en: Thelma is 49 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with four children. Thelma sells snacks like rice and cassava cakes. She has had this business for 8 years. She has requested a loan for PHP 11,000 to buy raw ingredients needed to make her rice cakes. Thelma has been a member of HSPFI since 2010. In the future, she hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy raw ingredients needed for rice cakes

loans.name: Paterna Aclep Group

texts.en:
Paterna is married with 3 children. She is 58 years old and lives in the Philippines.  She has been a farmer for 16 years, and grows corn to earn a living. She has requested a loan to purchase fertilizers for her corn planting. 

Paterna has been a member of PMPC for 2 years. She is the leader of a 5 person group.  Although they borrow as a group, each member of the group has her own business.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers for her corn planting.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to purchase more stones for use in her quarry.

loans.name: Rose's Group

texts.en:
Rose is 22 years old and lives in the town of Kireka in the Kampala central region of Uganda. She is single and has two children, both of whom are currently in school. Rose has a small hotel business, which she has run for four years.
To help expand her business, Rose has requested a loan of 400,000 Ugandan Shillings from Kiva partner, BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase chairs and food for the hotel. With the help of her loan from BRAC, Rose hopes to generate greater profits and pay school fees for her children. In the future, she hopes to open another hotel business.
Rose is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has aided her prospects for the future by helping improve her business.

loans.use: to purchase chairs and food for her hotel.

loans.name: Carolyn

texts.en:
Carolyn is 35 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with 4 children. For 5 years she has had a retail shop that sells breads, food seasonings & canned goods. She has requested a loan for PHP 5,000 to buy more canned goods, breads & beverages.

Carolyn is a new member of HSPFI.  In the future, she hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy canned goods, breads & beverages

loans.name: Rozi's Group

texts.en:
Rozi is a widow and has a son. Her son is still young and is a teacher by profession. He has completed his intermediate studies and is also continuing his education along with his job. 

Rozi lives with her two brothers. She doesn’t want to be a burden on her brothers, and that’s why she operates a clothes-sewing business from her home. She is very skillful and receives a good number of orders every month from her community clients.

Her elder brother has a scrap business while youngest one lives abroad. 

She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for the betterment of her elder brother’s business. With the loan, he will buy scrap in larger quantity to be able to meet the demand of his customers and increase his earnings. 

He has been operating his business for the past 15 years and Rozi is very confident that an investment will be a productive one for him.

loans.use: To buy scrap.

loans.name: Wilson

texts.en:
Wilson is 50 years old and lives in the Philippines. He is married with 2 children. For 3 years he has had a shop that sells breads, biscuits & candies. He requested a loan for PHP 5,000 to buy canned goods, snacks & beverages.

Wilson is a new member of HSPFI.  In the future, he hopes to improve his business.

loans.use: to buy canned goods, snacks & beverages

loans.name: Karoti Group

texts.en:
Nimulike, who is in her early thirties, is married with two children. The elder one goes to school.  She has been a food vendor for one year now at a place called Tegeta, some 10 kilometers from the city center. She works from 5am to 5:30pm daily and is able to make a good monthly profit.

This will be Nimulike’s 2nd loan from Tujijenge Tanzania.  She used the previous loan to increase her capital, and managed to sell more food. She has paid back her loan successfully.  She wants a new loan to buy more food stuff for making more and better quality food.  Her dream is to one day open a shop and sell drinks at wholesale prices.

She will share this loan with her loan group ("Karoti") which has a total of 15 members, who will hold each other accountable in paying back their loans.

loans.use: To buy more food stuff for the food market.

loans.name: Annet's Group

texts.en:
Annet is 22 years old and lives in the town of Kyengera in the Kampala central region of Uganda. She is married and has two children, both of whom are currently in school. Annet has a stone quarrying business, which she has run for seven years. She has a second business raising pigs for resale.
To help expand her business, Annet has requested a loan of 200,000 Ugandan Shillings from Kiva partner, BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase quarried stones for resale and pig feed. With the help of her loan from BRAC, Annet hopes to generate greater profits and pay school fees for her children. In the future, she hopes to own a poultry farm.
Annet is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has aided her prospects for the future by helping her improve her business.

loans.use: to purchase quarried stones for resale and pig feed.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase fertilizers

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 50-year-old married woman living with her husband and three children; two of them are still attending school. In 2000, she started working at producing homemade food such as bread, olive oil, etc. She sells her products to local customers. In parallel, she works as a housekeeper for clients who request her to clean their houses. She works hard in both jobs to be able to satisfy her family needs. 

Today, she is requesting to borrow $600 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l to increase her inventory of food products in order to increase her business productivity and therefore her sales. She hopes that the loan will help her meet her business objectives.

loans.use: to increase her inventory of food products.

loans.name: Victor

texts.en: Victor, 29, is married and has three children who attend school.  For two years, he has been operating a retail shop.  He was previously employed in an industry.  Since he joined Faulu Kenya, he has become financially stable because he has managed to improve his business. He dreams of venturing into more business in the future so as to generate more income.  He has requested 15, 000 Kenyan shillings to open another retail shop.

loans.use: To open another retail shop

loans.name: Sameiha

texts.en:
Sameiha is a 38-year-old wife and mother of two daughters and two sons. Sameiha's husband and oldest son, who appears in the picture instead of his conservative mother, work in the grocery store the family owns.

Sameiha took out a loan from FATEN to prepare the other half of the store to be used for more goods and grocery items for sale.

Sameiha's daughters and sons are school students.

loans.use: to expand the space of the store to display more goods.

loans.name: Hanaa

texts.en:
Hanaa is a 45-year-old housewife who always wanted to be a florist but, because of having five children to raise, she could not do it.
After her children grew up, Hanna had not forgotten her dream, so she decided five years ago to follow her passion and start at home as a florist, arranging flowers for special occasions. Florists shops in the area have found that Hanaa has a talent and an artistic way when arranging vases or bouquet of flowers for weddings and other occasions, so they decided to work with her selling what she makes in their stores. Now Hanaa is applying for a loan to buy more materials to increase her productivity as she also wants to start working with straw as a decoration for bouquets.

Since Hanaa is a conservative person, she agreed that her son, Mohammad, would appear in the picture.

loans.use: to buy more materials to increase her productivity as a florist.

loans.name: Milagros

texts.en:
Milagros is single. She is 48 years old and lives in the Philippines.  She has been a farmer for 5 years, and sell coconuts to earn a living. She has requested a loan to purchase more coconuts for her business. 

Milagros has been a member of PMPC for one year. In the future, she hopes to support her immediate family members financially.

loans.use: to purchase more coconuts for her business.

loans.name: Cissy

texts.en:
Cissy is 21 years old and lives in the town of Kyengera in the Kampala central region of Uganda. She is single and has no children. Cissy has a dairy farm business, which sells milk and bread, which she has run for two years.
To help expand her business, Cissy has requested a loan of 400,000 Ugandan Shillings from Kiva partner, BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase milk and bread for resale. With the help of her loan from BRAC, Cissy hopes to generate greater profits and buy food for her family. In the future, she hopes to expand her business further.
Cissy is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by teaching her how to save.

loans.use: to purchase milk and bread for resale.

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en: This Kiva borrower is a 29-year-old married woman living with her husband and one young child. She started her business selling accessories from her home. Today, she is the proud owner of an accessories and perfumes shop. She has been working hard in her store since 2007. She cooperates with her husband, who works as a blacksmith, to pay for the family's expenses. She is requesting a loan of $900 from Kiva's partner, Ameen s.a.l., to increase her store’s inventory of accessories and perfumes. She notes that the diversity of her merchandise selection will attract more clients and therefore increase her sales. In the future, she is planning to also sell women's bags and clothes in her shop.

loans.use: to increase her store’s inventory of accessories and perfumes.

loans.name: Akylbek

texts.en:
Akylbek is 33, married, and has four children between the ages of 5 and 15. He is a final-year student at the State University, and is also a businessman engaged in cattle-breeding.  He started his business with the initial capital of 10,000 KGS and managed to develop it to a point where the monthly profit is 5,000 – 10,000 KGS. In order to broaden his business by fattening and reselling colts, he has applied for a loan of 100,000 KGS.  With the revenue, Akylbek plans to reconstruct the barn for his cattle and save money for the higher education of his elder son. 

Bai-Tushum and Partners is one of the leading Microfinance Institutions in Kyrgyzstan. It uses Kiva funding to target the especially vulnerable population. As a reliable financial partner, Bai-Tushum contributes to the economic development of the Kyrgyz Republic through the delivery of microfinance services in rural and urban areas, which lead to increased employment and meet the interests of its clients and investors.

loans.use: to purchase cattle

loans.name: Flavia's Group

texts.en:
Flavia is 22 years old and lives in the town of Kyengera in the Kampala central region of Uganda. She is married and has two children, one of whom is currently in school. Flavia has a poultry farm business, which she has run for four years.
To help expand her business, Flavia has requested a loan of 600,000 Ugandan Shillings from Kiva partner, BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more chickens for resale. With the help of her loan from BRAC, Flavia hopes to generate greater profits and take care of herself – for example, by buying new clothes. In the future, she hopes to expand her business further.
Flavia is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by improving her business.

loans.use: to purchase more chickens for resale.

loans.name: Rafia's Group

texts.en:
Rafia is 43 years old and has given birth to three children. Her son sells clothes while her two daughters are students. Her husband has a gram flour [chickpea flour] selling business. It is used in making traditional Punjabi foods called samosas and pakoras and it is also used in the making of sweet dishes. 

Rafia is a seamstress; sewing clothes for her neighbor clients to share the financial burden with her husband. She is very skillful and receives a good number of orders every month. Besides her work, she also carries out her responsibilities as a housewife very well. 

Rafia has applied for a loan from Kiva's partner, Asasah, for her husband who wants to buy gram flour in larger quantities to sell and increase his earnings. Rafia is very confident that an investment will help him improve the financial condition of his business. She is a regular user of Asasah loans, and this is her third loan application. In previous years, she has maintained good credit behavior and never missed a meeting.

In the photo, the lady raising her hand is Rafia.

loans.use: to buy gram flour to sell.

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en: Agnes is 35 years old and hard working.  She is married and blessed with two children aged 8 and 3. For seven years, she has been running a general shop. Thanks to Faulu Kenya she has learned business management skills. She hopes to expand her business into wholesale in the future.  She is requesting 70,000 Kenyan shillings to buy rice, sugar, and farming equipment.

loans.use: To buy rice, sugar, and farming equipment

loans.name: Faten

texts.en:
Faten is a 22-year-old married woman who lives in Jabalia Refugee Camp in Gaza Strip. Faten's husband has a barber shop in the refugee camp. He wants to purchase creams and hair products for the barber shop. Faten took out a loan from FATEN to pay for the products her husband wants to purchase.

Faten is a conservative woman; therefore, her husband is photographed instead.

loans.use: to purchase creams and hair products for barber shop use.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase the materials to produce more weaving.

loans.name: Margret

texts.en:
Margret is 22 years old and lives in the town of Kyengera in the Kampala central region of Uganda. She is married and has two children, both of whom are currently in school. Margret has a small retail shop business, which sells essential commodities such as sugar and soap. She has run this business for three years. She also has a second business selling charcoal  
To help expand her business, Margret has requested a loan of 400,000 Ugandan Shillings from Kiva partner, BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase sugar, soap, rice and cooking oil for resale. With the help of her loan from BRAC, Margret hopes to generate greater profits and take care of herself – for example, buying new clothes and shoes. In the future, she hopes to own a salon.  
Margret is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by teaching her skills in how to save money.

loans.use: to purchase sugar, soap, rice and cooking oil for resale.

loans.name: Arcily Pacatan Group

texts.en: Arcily is married and has a child. Arcily is 31 years old and lives in the Philippines. Arcily is a farmer and she grows cows and goats to earn a living. She has been doing this for 2 years. She has requested a loan to purchase baby livestock. Arcily has been a member of PMPC for 2 years. In the future, Arcily hopes to save the extra income as a reserve for future emergencies. Arcily is the leader of a two person group.  Although they borrow as a group, each member of the group has their own business.

loans.use: To purchase baby livestock.

loans.name: Leonila

texts.en:
Leonila is married with 4 children. Leonila is 48 years old and lives in Dapaon, Sindangan, Zamboanga del Norte.

Leonila makes and sells Ice Candy to earn a living and has had this business for one year. She has requested a loan to buy wheels, chains, bearings, sprockets and other parts of a motorcycle.

Leonila has been a member of PMPC for one year. In the future, Leonila hopes to have her own store..

loans.use: To buy spare parts like wheels, chains, and other motor parts.

loans.name: Luzviminda

texts.en:
Luzviminda is a 58-year-old married woman. She lives in the community of Sto. Niño, South Cotabato. Her husband is a farmer in their community.  She and her husband till their small rice farm to be able to raise income for their family.

With the loan coming from Community Economic Ventures Inc. she could buy fertilizers, seeds, and insecticides.

In the future, Luzviminda hopes to have a bigger farm and more profits for her family.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers, seeds, and insecticides.

loans.name: Lucy

texts.en:
Lucy is a fast learner and hard working. She is married and blessed with two children; one child is one years old and the other is 4 years old. She has been running a retail shop for the last two years. She also owns a cafeteria which earns her extra income.  In addition, she does tailoring.  In the next five years, she hopes to have a stable and ample capital base and a business that runs on honesty and integrity.  

She wants 20, 000 Kenyan shillings to buy a container as a storage facility.

loans.use: To buy a container as a storage facility.

loans.name: Mary Jane

texts.en: Mary Jane, a 46-year-old woman who lives in the community of Sto. Nino South Cotabato, is married to a farmer with whom she cultivates their small rice farm to support their family. Her average income is Php 19,000 per harvest. With her loan from Community Economic Ventures Inc., Mary Jane will buy fertilizers, seeds and insecticides. In the future, she hopes to have a bigger farm and more profit for her family.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers, seeds and insecticides.

loans.name: Kibanga Development Group

texts.en: 41 year old Fatia is a happily married mother of two. All her children are in school. Fatia has been in a restaurant business for close to four years now. Inspiration from her close friend is what made her start up this business. Before that, she was more inclined to fishing. Fatia believes her determination will see her make further progress in the near future. It has only been four years, but she feels like a past master already. This makes her upbeat. She feels she can shoulder most of her responsibilities with less disquiet using the business insight she has. Fatia still runs her fishing business though, but on a small scale now. Weekly, this business generates her profits summing up to shillings 65,000. She says she will use the proceeds from the kiva loan to purchase more food stuffs.

loans.use: to purchase more food stuffs.

loans.name: Raeda

texts.en:
Raeda is a young woman from Jabalia Refugee Camp in Gaza Strip. Raeda has two daughters and two sons. She took out a loan from FATEN to purchase furniture for her daughters. The four children used to share the same room but, now that they are growing up, the children need their own rooms. Raeda's husband is an employee and can't furnish the room from his salary, though he can pay FATEN back on a monthly basis.

Raeda's husband is photographed instead of her as she is a conservative woman (as are most of Gaza Strip inhabitants).

loans.use: to purchase home furniture for her daughters' room.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase flowers and design products.

loans.name: Merlyn

texts.en:
Merlyn is a married woman with five children. She is 48 years old. She has been in the rice farming business for quite a long time now.

Receiving a loan from Community Economic Ventures Inc. will help her continue her livelihood. She could buy fertilizers and seeds. 

In the future, Merlyn hopes to have a stable business.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers and seeds.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase building materials such as sands, woods, cement etc.

loans.name: George

texts.en:
George is 33 years old, married and has two children in school.  He has a quarrying business to earn a living for his family.  He has been in the business for two years with two employees.  Besides this, he runs a green grocery for extra income.  
Since joining Faulu Kenya, he has learned how to save his money and his business has improved.  He has requested 20,000 Kenyan shillings to buy mining tools and a wheelbarrow.

loans.use: To buy mining tools and a wheelbarrow.

loans.name: Helen Group

texts.en: Helen is married with two children. Helen is 37 years old and lives in the Philippines. Helen is a farmer and raises pigs to earn a living. She has been doing this for 10 years. She has requested a loan to purchase pigs. Helen has been a member of PMPC for 2 years. Helen is the leader of a 2 person group.  Although they borrow as a group, each member of the group has their own business.

loans.use: to purchase pigs.

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en: This Kiva borrower is a 38-year-old married man living with his wife and four school-age children. He is from Lebanon. Over the years, he has had a good experience working as a painter. In 2006, he opened a small shop where he started to sell a wide range of painting products and all related tools. He is the main income provider of the family. Today, he is requesting to borrow $2,000 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to purchase additional painting products and tools. In the future, he hopes to continue the growth of his business and be able to further expand his business operation.

loans.use: to purchase additional painting products and tools

loans.name: Shazia's Group

texts.en:
Shazia is 40 years old and married with four children: three sons and a daughter.  Only her daughter is able to get an education. Her eldest son has a clothes selling business and her second son sells CDs and DVDs. Her husband has a welding business. He provides spare parts, repair and iron welding services to his clients at cheap rates. 

Shazia is very supportive and knows that alone her husband is unable to meet the financial requirements of his family. That’s why she sews clothes for her neighboring customers. She is very skillful and earns a reasonably good income from her business. She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for the expansion of her husband’s welding business. With the loan, he will buy a welding machine that will allow him to provide better quality services to his customers and earn more profits. He is experienced in his work and has been operating his business for the past 30 years. Shazia is hopeful that a loan will bring more profits to him and improve her family’s financial conditions.  She is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her second loan application. In the previous loan year, she established good credit behavior and never missed any meeting. 

Note: In the photo, the lady raising her hand is Shazia.

loans.use: To buy a welding machine

loans.name: Minda

texts.en:
Minda is a 48-year old married woman with five children. The oldest child is 25. Minda’s husband works as a farmer.

Minda is also a farmer. She helps her husband till their land located in Sto. Niño, South Cotabato. Minda has been growing rice for 8 years. She also raises pigs and goats.

This loan will be used to purchase seeds and fertilizers.  In the future, Minda hopes to own a bigger farm.

loans.use: to purchase seeds and fertilizers.

loans.name: Salome

texts.en:
Salome, a 73-year-old, has ten children between 21 and 49 years old.  She is a farmer who grows pyrethrum in large-scale.  She has been farming for over 50 years.  Salome also does dairy farming to boost her income.  

Since Salome joined Faulu Kenya, she has learned how to save her money.  She has improved her farming with her previous loans.  She hopes to become one of the major suppliers of pyrethrum in the future.  She needs 80,000 Kes to buy more pyrethrum seedlings.

loans.use: To buy more pyrethrum seedlings.

loans.name: Murodali

texts.ru: Муродали проживает в городе Куляб. Ему 21 год. Он холост. Живет вместе с родителями. У него среднее образование. Он открыл продуктовый магазин в селе Куйбешев.  В этой области он работает уже полтора года. Муродали берет кредит для увеличения ассортимента товара. То есть он хочет купить булочки, консервированные товары, сахар, конфеты, фрукты, мыло и туалетную бумагу.
texts.en: Murodali lives in the city of Kulob. He is 21 years old and single. He lives with his parents. He has a secondary education. He opened a grocery shop in Kuybeshev village. He has been doing this work for a year and a half. Murodali is taking out a loan to increase the variety of goods he sells.  In other words, he wishes to buy buns, canned goods, sugar, sweets, fruit, soap, and toilet paper.

loans.use: to increase the variety of goods he sells

loans.name: Marigee Group

texts.en:
Marigee is single, 32 years old, and lives in the Philippines.  Marigee is a farmer and raises cow and goats to earn a living. She has been doing this for 8 years. She has requested a loan to purchase two cows and one goat. 

Marigee has been a member of PMPC for 3 years. Marigee is the leader of a 2 person group.  Although they borrow as a group, each member of the group has their own business.

loans.use: to purchase two cows and one goat.

loans.name: Isisekelo Group

texts.en:
Siphiwe is 60 years old and single with six children between the ages of 21 and 39 years old, one of which attends school. She runs a clothing business in Kwa Zulu Natal of Empangeni in South Africa. In the photo she is pictured rasing her hand.

She has been in this business for 7 years selling clothes to people who are working in farms. She also receives income from the goverment old age pension fund. Siphiwe requested this loan through WDB and Kiva to buy clothes for resale. She says that the extra income form this loan will help her improove her life and her famillies buy putting food on the table and paying for her children's school fees. She faces a challenge of customers who buy on credit and fail to pay on time. In the future, she would like to see her business grow.

loans.use: To buy clothes for resale.

loans.name: Hassan

texts.en:
Hassan is 39 years old and married with 4 children, ages between 7 and 18.  He runs a local food store in Waterloo near Freetown.

Hassan has been in this business for 7 years and sells cassava root, groundnuts and Palm oil at his store. This business is the only source of income. He says that the main challenge to his business is price fluctuation.

He requested this loan through BRAC Sierra Leone to purchas local food stuff items. Hassan says that the extra income from this loan will help him improve the standard of his living. In the future, he would like to expand his business more.

loans.use: To purchase more groundnuts and palm oil.

loans.name: Myrna

texts.en:
Myrna is 56 years old. She is a married woman with three children, and her husband works as a farmer.

Myrna is in the hog raising business. She raises pigs for fattening and sells them at her town's local market. She also owns a sari-sari store where she sells items like canned goods, eggs, and soft drinks. Myrna also helps her husband at their rice farm when she can.

Myrna's loan will be used to purchase two piglets, feed, and vitamins. She hopes her hog raising business will improve.

loans.use: to purchase two piglets, feed, and vitamins.

loans.name: Yasmeen's Group

texts.en:
Yasmeen is 54 years old, married and has five sons. All of her sons are young. Her eldest son sells clothes. Her second son is a rickshaw driver and her third son operates a clothes selling business too. Yasmeen herself is a seamstress and sews clothes for her neighborhood clients. She has been operating her business for many years and is well known among her clients for her good quality work. 

She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her second son. With the loan, he will buy a new body for his rickshaw and do some repair works so it works smoothly and attracts many passengers to get service from him due to his well-conditioned rickshaw.  
He has been operating his transport business for the past eight years and Yasmeen is hopeful that after the loan investment, his business will grow better and his income will increase. Yasmeen is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her second loan application. In her previous loan year, she paid her installments on time and never missed any meeting. 

Note: In the photo, the lady raising her hand is Yasmeen.

loans.use: To repair and buy a new rickshaw body

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en: This Kiva borrower is a 43-year-old married woman from Lebanon. She is living with her husband and four children, two of whom are still attending school. She has owned a mini-market in her village since 2009. She sells in her grocery store all types of food products like juices, breads etc. She cooperates with her husband who works in the construction field to be able to handle the heavy living expenses. Today, she is requesting to borrow $2,000 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to improve her business and further expand it by increasing her store’s inventory. She is very positive and hopes that the loan will help her achieve a significant growth in her business.

loans.use: to increase her store’s inventory

loans.name: Nelida

texts.en:
Nelida is 46 years old. She is a married woman with two children. Nelida and her husband are both farmers. She helps her husband grow rice and sell their harvest. Her husband mainly manages the farm and Nelida also runs their sari-sari store. She sells items like biscuits and vinegar.

This loan will be used to purchase seeds and fertilizer. In the future, Nelida hopes her children will succeed. She also hopes to improve her living conditions.

loans.use: to purchase seeds and fertilizer.

loans.name: Manday Group

texts.en:
Merlinda is married, with children. She is 36 years old and lives in the Philippines. Merlinda is a farmer and grows corn to earn a living. She has been doing this for 18 years. She has requested a loan to purchase 10 sacks of fertilizer. 

Merlinda has been a member of PMPC for three years. She is the leader of this three-person group. Although they borrow as a group, each member of the group has her own business.

loans.use: to purchase 10 sacks of fertilizer.

loans.name: Andrea

texts.en:
This is Andrea, 56, a resident of Pasay City, Philippines. She is married to Felipe, a cook in a food stall, and is the mother of five children. Four of her children are already working, while the youngest is in high school. By the grace of God, Andrea has managed to support her older children's schooling up to college level. At this time, she is working hard to send her youngest to college. This is a dream for most poor Filipino parents; Andrea herself has been an undergraduate, and she believes that a college diploma is the best inheritance parents can leave to their children.

Andrea maintains a direct selling business. She sells clothing, footwear, undergarments, cosmetics, and other products through the popular direct selling brands like Avon, Fullerlife, Natasha, Boardwalk, Marikina Shoe Exchange, and other direct selling brands. A customer's order is bought in cash by the dealer and then given to the customer with a one-month-to-pay credit. Dealers' prices are lower than those in the catalogue, and these are the profits that dealers are investing on as their income. Aside from direct selling, she sells breakfast every morning. Her regular customers are her neighbours and the local community. She earns a minimum of Php 510 in sales every week.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a loan of Php 10,000. She will be using the loan to buy orders for her customers. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.  

Andrea fervently hopes that her child will be able to graduate one day. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week and to draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for orders and products that she is selling.

loans.name: Jumwa

texts.en:
Jumwa is a married woman with four children. Two of them attend school while two are still too young for school. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

For the past year, she has operated a charcoal selling business, selling at the market to her neighbours and passers-by. She faces a major challenge in transporting charcoal from the village to the market for sale. She dreams of constructing houses in the future.

With the loan of Kshs 20,000, she wants to purchase sacks of charcoal for sale. She decided to join Yehu to get access to loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase sacks of charcoal for sale.

loans.name: Riziki Mupya Group

texts.fr: La cliente Nankafu, représentante du groupe d’affaire « Riziki Mupya »,  est entrepreneur, âgée de 47 ans, mariée, mère de 13 enfants, tous étudient, parmi lequel, il y a des juristes  avocats et des universitaires. Elle est vendeuse de friperie et distributeur agrégée des  cartes des unités de téléphone cellulaire. Son mari est un haut fonctionnaire de la Régie de voies ariennes (RVA). Elle étale ses marchandise  au long de la route, à l’entrée de la douane RD Congo-Rwanda. Il y a 15 ans révolus qu’elle exerce cette activité. Cependant, elle vient de réaliser  10 cycles avec le crédit de Hekima. Ce nouveau crédit doit lui servir  de s’approvisionner  avec  2 ballons de friperies.  En plus, elle ambitionne scolariser ses enfants.  La cliente remercie Hekima pour  ses actions en faveur de pauvres femmes exclues de banque classique. Il sied de signaler que le groupe d’affaire « Riziki Mupya» est majoritairement féminins.
texts.en: Nankafu is a client who represents the Riziki Mupya group. She is a 47 year old businesswoman, married and mother to 13 children all of whom are students and among whom there are solicitors, lawyers, and university students. She is a second hand clothes shopkeeper and accredited distributer of mobile phone cards. Her husband is a high ranking government official of the State Airways Agency (RVA).She lays out her merchandise at the roadside, at the entry to the RD Congo-Rwanda customs post. She has been practicing this activity for fifteen years. However, she has just reached the end of a cycle of 10 loans with the Hekima credit organisation. This new loan will enable her to purchase two balls of second hand clothing. In addition she intends to send her children to school. The client is grateful to Hekima for their actions in favour of poor women who are excluded from classic banking institutions. It should be noted that the Riziki Mupya business group is largely composed of women.

loans.use: to purchase  two balls of second hand clothing.

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Saodat

texts.ru: Саодат проживает в городе Куляб. Ей 31 год. Она разведена.  У нее один ребенок. Она живет вместе с родителями. В их семье все занимаются торговлей. Сама Саодат имеет высшее педагогическое образование. Она работает в средней школе, преподает математику младшим классам. Кроме того она занимается торговлей на рынке «Саховат». Она арендует помещение, где открыла магазин детской одежды. В этой области она уже 5 лет. Кредит берет для покупки детских костюмчиков.
texts.en: Saodat lives in the city of Kulob. She is 31 years old, divorced, and has one child. She lives with her parents. Everyone in her family works in trade.   Saodat has a higher education in pedagogy. She works in a middle school where she teaches mathematics to the younger grades. Additionally, she trades in the Sakhovat market. She rents a space where she has opened a shop selling children's clothes. She has been doing this work for five years.  She is taking out a loan to buy children's outfits.

loans.use: to buy children's outfits.

loans.name: Kadzo

texts.en:
Kadzu is a married woman with four children, all of whom are adults. She lives in a rental house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

For the past 10 years, she has operated a charcoal-selling business, selling at the market to her neighbours and passers-by. She faces a major challenge in transportation because of poor roads. She dreams of establishing a retail shop business in the future.

With the loan of Kshs 20,000, she wants to purchase bundles of charcoal for sale. She decided to join Yehu to get access to loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase bundles of charcoal for sale.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase more weaves, chemicals, and hair products for her salon.

loans.name: Celia

texts.en:
This is Celia, 46, a resident of Pasay City, Philippines. She is a mother of two children. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses and to support her children’s schooling — a dream for most poor Filipino parents who, like Celia, believe that a college diploma is the best thing parents could leave to their children.

Celia operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store, which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, 5 Philippines pesos (Php) worth of cooking oil, or an egg. Celia earns by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece. Aside from the store, she is also into direct selling. She sells clothing, footwear, undergarments, cosmetics and other products. Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of Php 470 in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a Php 10,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Celia dreams to be able to give all her children a good and high quality education through all her hard work in her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week, where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the word of God, build social capital, and repay micro-finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for grocery products and inventory items needed in her variety store.

loans.name: Ricardo

texts.en:
Ricardo spent his entire life being a farmer. Now, he is 57 years old and married. His wife is also a farmer. He has doing this business for 30 years now.

Aside from rice, he also raises swine to supplement their family income. He earns about 26,500 Philippines pesos (PHP) per harvest.

Ricardo needs a loan to support his livelihood. The loan will help him buy seeds, fertilizers and pig feed.

In the future, Ricardo hopes to have an improved living situation.

loans.use: to buy seeds, fertilizers and pig feed.

loans.name: Anjelina

texts.en:
Anjelina runs a retail shop selling soap and tea leaves. Her shop is located close to her home and she sells these goods to local residents. Anjelina intends to use her loan to stock up on soap. 

Anjelina hopes to become a wholesaler of tea leaves. She also dreams of owning her own house so she can avoid paying rent. Anjelina describes herself as polite and caring.

loans.use: to stock up on soap she intends to resell.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to purchase more pigs.

loans.name: Divina Gracia

texts.en:
This is Divina, 59, a resident of Pasay City, Philippines. She is a widow and the mother of three children, all of whom are already working, and two of whom are settled down with their own families. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for her everyday expenses.

Divina operates a food stall. In the Philippines, the whole working community and most of the families only eat home-cooked meals during evenings where all of the family members are at home to take part in the meal. This is not only a usual family tradition but a matter of convenience and frugal living. It is considered a waste of money and time to spend cooking gas and food for one to two persons when buying cooked rice and viands (dishes) cost less than raw food. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of 730 Philippines pesos (Php) in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a Php15,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy more quantities of products like meats, rice, vegetables, condiments and seasonings. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.  

Divina Gracia hopes to be able to expand soon, just as she hopes to have her own house and lot in a prominent subdivision in a nice location. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week, where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the word of God, build social capital and pay micro-finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for products and ingredients used in her business.

loans.name: Betty

texts.en:
Betty is 33 years old, married, and has a 6-year-old daughter. She runs a beauty salon and a cereal shop within a busy market. Betty has hired two employees and has been running her business for 10 years. She intends to use her loan to purchase more cereal that she hopes to resell. 

Betty hopes to use the profit from her business to provide her daughter with a quality education. She would also like to open a cosmetics shop around her hometown. Betty describes herself as polite and welcoming.

loans.use: to purchase more cereal she intends to resell.

loans.name: Hadija

texts.en:
Hadija is a married woman with five children, all of whom attend school. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family and school fees. 

For the past three years, she has operated a grocery-selling business, selling from home to her neighbors and passersby. Hadija faces a major challenge in the high cost of transportation and seasonality in her business. She dreams of expanding her business and selling wholesale in the future.

With the 20,000 Kenyan shillings, she wants to purchase sacks of vegetables and fruits for sale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase sacks of vegetables and fruits for sale.

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en:
This is Teresita, 45, a resident of Caloocan City, Philippines. She is married to Fernando, a technician, and is also a stay-at-home mother who manages the household while she attends to her business.

Teresita operates a photocopying business. She finds that there is more need for her services now than previously as customer demand has increased. Her main customers are students who require her services for their schoolwork. She also has customers who require photocopying for documents, form replication and so forth. Her regular customers are students from the school near her business site and members of the local community. Teresita earns a minimum of 300 Philippines pesos (PHP) profit every day.

To help her continue to operate her business, Teresita is requesting a 22,000 PHP loan. She will use the loan to buy bond paper, toners and ink, and other supplies for her business. She will also invest a portion of the loan to buy spare parts and pay repair fees for her photocopying machine. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.

Teresita dreams of being able to give her all her children a good, high quality education through all her hard work in her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week, where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the word of God, build social capital and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for bond paper, toners and ink, and other supplies for her business.

loans.name: Susan

texts.en:
Susan is a 48-year-old married woman with five children. She lives in the town of Sto. Nino, South Cotabato. Susan's husband works as a farmer.

Susan has been growing rice for 25 years. She earns about 15,000 Philippines pesos (PHP) per month from farming. Susan is also into hog-raising.

This loan will be used to purchase seeds, feeds and fertilizers. Susan hopes for this loan to help improve their harvest.

loans.use: to purchase seeds, feeds and fertilizers.

loans.name: Wilfrida

texts.en:
Wilfrida is 48 years old, married, and has four children, ages 10 to 30. She sells sugar, Unga Ngaro, Unga Ugali, and rice to locals at a busy market center. Wilfrida intends to use her loan to purchase more sugar, flour, and maize.

Wilfrida hopes to open several businesses in the area. She describes herself as focused and determined.

loans.use: to purchase more sugar, flour, and maize.

loans.name: Chrisphine

texts.en:
Chrisphine is 39 years old. He is married and is blessed with 10 children between 2 and 16 years old. He has been selling small fish (omena) for 18 years. He supplements his earnings from his rental houses. In the next five years, he wants to be a wholesaler and supplier of fish in his local community, and he hopes and dreams that he will be able to open up several outlets and own several big shops. He is grateful to Faulu Kenya for boosting his business financially and for the managerial advices that has enabled him to run his business effectively and efficiently.

He wants 40,000 Kenyan Shillings to buy small fish (omena).

loans.use: to buy small fish.

loans.name: Chona

texts.en:
Chona is 42 years old and lives in Oroquieta City. She is married with three children.

Chona has a jewelry repair business and earns approximately PHP 3000 each month doing this type of work. She has a requested a loan to purchase additional equipment for her jewelry repair shop.

Chona has been a member of PMPC for three years.

loans.use: to purchase additional equipment for her jewelry repair shop.

loans.name: Carmelita

texts.en:
Carmelita is 56 years old and lives in Doña Josefa, Sindangan, Zamboanga del Norte. She is married with seven children.

Carmelita works in the fish industry and sells fish for a living. She has been doing this for 15 years. She has requested a loan to pay for her fishermen's salary.

Carmelita has been a member of PMPC for three years. In the future, Carmelita hopes to have an additional unit of fish vessel.

loans.use: to pay for her fishermen's salary.

location.town: Doña Josefa, Sindangan, Zamboanga del Norte

loans.name: Khvan

texts.en:
Mrs. Khvan, 33, is married and the mother of four teenage children who are not yet employed. Her husband is 44 years old and a local farmer who works in the fields.

For over a year Mrs. Khvan has made a living by selling different kinds of fresh fish in the Ornlong Veng district of Siem Reap Province. She always gets up early in the morning in order to buy fish from local fisherman, and she hurries to sell them. She currently earns an average of $3 a day.

Mrs. Khvan is an assiduous woman who never wastes time while engaging in her business activities. As a result of the increasing needs of her customers, Mrs. Khvan is applying for a loan so she can purchase more fish to sell and plant potatoes as well.

loans.use: to purchase more fish to sell and potatoes to plant.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more inventory of soft drinks, instant noodles, milk, sugar etc. for her shop

loans.name: Mwanamisi

texts.en:
Mwanamisi is a married woman with three children, all of whom attend school. She owns a house that has electricity but not piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees for her children.

For the past three years, she has operated a retail shop, selling from home to her neighbours and passers-by. She also owns real estate houses which contribute to her other source of livelihood. Mwanamisi faces a major challenge of competition from other retail shop operators. She dreams of establishing another retail shop business in the future.

With the Kshs 20,000 she wants to purchase sacks of beans, sugar, bundles of wheat flour and maize flour. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase sacks of beans, sugar, bundles of wheat flour and maize flour.

loans.name: Yobesh

texts.en:
Yobesh is 40 years old and a hardworking businessman. He is married and blessed with three children. For the last four years, he has been doing a welding business. He wants 20,000 Kenyan shillings to buy iron sheets and square tubes.

He has a dream of building rental houses in the future. He is thankful to Faulu Kenya for helping him to learn the art of keeping business records.

loans.use: to buy iron sheets and square tubes

loans.name: Aida

texts.en:
Aida is a married woman with one child who attends school. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

For the past two years she has operated a food stall business, selling at the market to her neighbours. In addition, she also sells clothes from door to door, which contributes to her other source of income. She faces a major challenge of competition from other clothes sellers. Aida dreams of expanding her business in the future.

With the 20,000 KES, she wants to purchase sacks of beans, rice and cooking fat oil. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase sacks of beans, rice and cooking fat oil

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase more piglets to breed and then sell.

loans.name: Razia's Group

texts.en:
Razia is a housewife who does her household responsibilities by staying at home.  She is very active and performs her daily routine tasks with a great sense of responsibility. She is a mother of three children; two of them study and her youngest daughter is only one year old. 

She lives in a combined family system along with her brother. Her brother has a rent-a-bike business. He rents motorbikes to people and charges on an hourly basis. His business is going well but he wants to improve it further. Therefore, Razia has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her brother who will buy another motorbike with the loan. This will help him provide his services to more people at a time and earn a better income. Her brother has been operating his business for the past five years and it is working well for him. Razia is hopeful that after the loan, it will increase his profits more.

loans.use: To buy another motorbike

loans.name: Fidel

texts.en:
Fidel is 35 years old, married, and has two children ages 3 and 7. He sells charcoal, timber, frames, firewood, basins, and tyres to local people in a busy area of town. Fidel has been running this business for 3 years and employs one person. Fidel hopes to use his loan to purchase more timber and machines for cutting timber. 

Fidel hopes to expand his business by opening a timber yard. He also hopes to pay for his children’s education using the proceeds from his business. Fidel describes himself as humble and spiritual.

loans.use: to purchase more timber and machines for cutting timber

loans.name: Lucy

texts.en:
Lucy is 59 years old and an ambitious business lady. She is married and she is the proud mother of four children. She has been operating a retail shop for the past twelve years. She needs 65,000 Kenyan shillings to buy rice, sugar and maize flour.

In the next five years, she wants to own her own store or business premise and later move to a level higher to own a supermarket. She is grateful to Faulu Kenya for instilling in her good business management skills.

loans.use: to buy rice, sugar and maize flour

loans.name: Sinakahle Group

texts.en:
Zimiphi is 45 years old and single with 5 children between the ages of 14 and 27. 3 of her children attend school. She runs an agricultural business in Kwa Zulu Natal of Empangeni in South Africa. In the photo, she is pictured raising her hand.

She has been in this business for 4 years, selling fermented milk and plants that she grows. Zimiphi requested this loan through WDB and Kiva to buy fermented milk and seeds. She says that the extra income from this loan will help her improve her life by sending her children to school. Zimiphi faces a lot of customers who take her stock on credit and fail to pay on time. In future, she would like to see her business grow and end up having a shelter for her business.

loans.use: to buy fermented milk and seeds

loans.name: Mejumaa

texts.en:
Mejumaa is a married woman with two school aged children.  She owns a house that has electricity but not piped water.  Her greatest monthly expense is school fees for her children.

Mejumaa has operated a food vending business for the past two years, selling in a shop to her neighbours and school going children.  She faces a major challenge of high cost of transportation to her place of operation.  Mejumaa dreams of expanding her business in the future.

With the KES 10,000 loan she wants to purchase bundles of maize flour, cooking fat oil and wheat flour.  She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: To purchase bundles of maize flour, cooking fat oil and wheat flour.

loans.name: Hasan

texts.en: Hasan is a 21-year-old man from Jabalia Refugee camp in Gaza Strip. Hasan has an internet cafe. Hasan wants to add a computer to the ones in the cafe. He took out a loan from FATEN to purchase the computer. Hasan, who is photographed in the picture here, lives with his parents and shares with his father the household expenses.

loans.use: to purchase a personal computer

loans.name: Tereza

texts.en: Tereza is from the village of Gharibjanyan in the Shirak region of Armenia.  She is married with a fourteen-year-old daughter and a sixteen-year-old son.  Tereza has a high school education and has been engaged in farming for the past eighteen years.  In addition to supporting her family she helps relatives living in the city with agricultural products grown on the family farm.  Tereza is looking for a loan to purchase potato seeds and fertilizer.  She expects this investment to increase the family income by twenty percent.  It is Tereza’s dream for both of her children to receive a university education, and she is saving some of the income from her farming business.  She enjoys living in Gharibjanyan surrounded by family and friends.

loans.use: to purchase potato seeds and fertilizer

loans.name: George

texts.en:
George is a married man with one child who is still too young for school.  He lives at a rental house that has electricity and piped water.  His greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

For the past three years, he has operated matatu (public service vehicle) business his potential customers are general passengers.  George faces a major challenge of rush hour timing in his business.  He dreams of becoming self-reliant in the future.

With the KES 60,000 loan he wants to renew his public service motor vehicle license and service his motor vehicle.  He decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost his business.

loans.use: To renew his public service motor vehicle license and service his motor vehicle.

loans.name: Arche De Noé Group

texts.fr: La cliente Mutima, représentante du groupe d’affaire « Arche de Noé»,  est entrepreneur, âgée de 50 ans, mariée, mère de 6 enfants, tous étudient, parmi les quels, il y a des universitaires et d’autres ont leurs propres foyers. Elle est vendeuse de friperie et sociétaire d’un atelier moderne de coupe couture. Son mari est un professeur de l’université. Elle étale ses marchandise  au long de la route, devant son domicile. Il y a 20 ans révolus qu’elle exerce ces activités. Cependant, elle vient de réaliser  9 cycles avec le crédit de Hekima. Ce nouveau crédit doit lui servir  de s’approvisionner  avec  2 ballons de friperies.  En plus, elle ambitionne scolariser ses enfants et construire une maison dans la parcelle qu’elle avait acheté des bénéfices cumulés de son business.  La cliente remercie Hekima pour  ses actions en faveur de pauvres femmes exclues de banque classique. Il sied de signaler que le groupe d’affaire « Arche de Noé» est majoritairement féminins.Certaines mamans clientes portent joyeusement leurs bébés dans leurs mains. et que d’autres figures sont difficilement visibles sur cette photo du groupe suite à l’espace et positionnement.
texts.en:
The client Mutima is the representative of the business group “Noah’s Ark,” is an entrepreneur, 50 years old, married, and the mother of six. All her children study; some are already university students and others have their own households. She sells used clothing and is a member of a modern sewing shop. Her husband is a university professor. She displays her goods by the road, in front of her home. She has been in this business for 20 years.

She just finished nine loan cycles with Hekima. This new loan will allow her to purchase two bales of used clothing. In addition, her goal is to provide for her children’s education and to buy a house on the land plot she has bought thanks to the income from her business. She thanks Hekima for its work in support of impoverished women who don’t have access to the classical bank system. It needs to be noted that the majority of “Noah’s Ark” group members are women. Some mothers are seen in the photo joyfully holding their babies; some women’s faces are hard to see because the entire group had to fit into the picture.

loans.use: to buy two bales of clothing

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Angelique

texts.en:
Angelique is 39 years old and married with six children. She has adopted one orphan.

Angelique owns a beauty salon and has been in this business for sixteen years. She employs five people in her salon. She works from 6:00 a.m. until 8:00 p.m. every day except Sunday.

Angelique has requested a loan from Kiva lenders to purchase more essential materials for her beauty salon such as shampoo, more chairs, more combs, etc. With this profit, Angelique will reinvest in her business and save for her future.

loans.use: To buy shampoo, more chairs, more combs, etc. for her salon.

loans.name: Joseph

texts.en:
Joseph is 33 years old and a hard working businessman.  He is married and is a proud father of two children ages 11 and 7 years old.  He has been selling second-hand shoes for the last ten years.  He wants 30,000 Kenyan shillings to buy more shoes.

In five years, he wants to open up a permanent business stall and he dreams of having a successful business.  He is grateful to Faulu Kenya for teaching him the art of customer care and how to save money.

loans.use: To buy shoes

loans.name: Mejumaa

texts.en:
Mejumaa is a married woman with two children, all of whom are still too young for school.  She owns a house that has electricity but not piped water.  Her greatest monthly expense is for the family.

For the past four years she has operated a tailoring business, making dresses and uniforms for sale from home to her neighbors and parents with school going children.  Mejumaa faces a major challenge of high cost of transportation incurred when purchasing materials for her business.  She dreams of becoming self reliant in the future.

With the KES 15,000 loan she wants to purchase clothing material and thread for her tailoring business.  She decided to work with Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: To purchase clothing material and thread for her tailoring business.

loans.name: Mariam

texts.en:
Mariam is a married woman with two children, all of whom attend school.  She lives at a rental house that has electricity and piped water.  Her greatest monthly expense is school fees for her children.

For the past two years, she has operated an open air food selling business, selling from home to her neighbours.  Mariam faces a major challenge of competition from other food sellers in the market.  She dreams of establishing a boutique business in the future.

With the KES 15,000 she wants to purchase bundles sugar, cooking fat oil, maize flour and cereals.  She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: To purchase bundles of sugar, cooking fat oil, maize flour and cereals.

loans.name: Susanna

texts.en: Susanna lives in the Shirak region of Armenia in the village of Akhouryan. She is the proud mother of five children - three sons (nineteen, twenty-six and twenty-seven years old) and two daughters (nine and twenty-four years old). Working on the family farm since high school Susanna has been able to support her family.  Being a lifelong resident of Akhuryan she would like to continue to expand her business.  Susanna is looking for a loan to purchase seeds and fertilizer.  She would also like to repair the cattle shed.  According to her business plan this investment will increase the family income by fifteen percent.  With the additional income Susanna will continue to grow the business and save money for her youngest daughter and son to attend university.  She is pleased with the services of microfinance.

loans.use: to purchase seeds and fertilizer

loans.name: Jaber

texts.en: Jaber is a 21-year-old man from Jablia Refugee camp. He inherited his profession from his father. Jaber transports passengers between Jabalia refugee camp and neighboring areas. Jaber took out a loan from FATEN to pay for car maintenance and painting. The car is in a very good shape and needs only painting and a regular check and maintenance. Jaber is photographed in the picture here.

loans.use: to pay for car painting and maintenance

loans.name: Tahira's Group

texts.en:
Tahira is a 33-year-old lady who operates a business selling utensils in her community. She does this work to share the financial burden with her husband. Her husband is also involved in the same business. He sells utensils to different utensil shops and to different areas of the community. He has been operating this business for the past 14 years.
  
Tahira is a mother of three children: two sons and a daughter. Her daughter reads in 7th standard and her eldest son reads in 4th standard. Her younger son is only three years old. Tahira knows the value of education because she also got her education until 5th standard but unfortunately, she couldn’t study further due to the poor financial condition of her parents. That’s why she works hard to give her children a better future. 
 
She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah to grow her husband’s business. With the loan, her husband will buy utensils of plastic, steel and glass and meet the requirements of his customers for earning better profits. Tahira hopes that the loan investment will take her husband to a better position and improve the financial condition of his business. 

Note: In the photo, the lady with a book (called Asasah Passbook) is Tahira.

loans.use: To buy utensils to sell

loans.name: Bejan

texts.ru: Бежан проживает в городе Куляб. Ему 31 год. Он женат. У него трое детей. Его жена занимается торговлей парфюмерии. Сам Бежан имеет среднее образование. Он предоставляет услугу. В основном он занимается ремонтом мобильных телефонов. Этим видом деятельности Бежан занимается 8 лет. Целью кредита является приобретение необходимых инструментов для ремонта мобильных телефонов.
texts.en: Bejan lives in the city of Kulob. He is 31 years old, married, and has three children. His wife sells perfume. Bejan has a secondary education. He provides a service. Basically, he is repairs mobile phones. He has been doing this work for eight years.  He is taking out a loan to buy tools necessary to repair mobile phones.

loans.use: to buy tools necessary to repair mobile phones.

loans.name: John

texts.en:
John is 22 years old and a hard-working businessman. He is married and the proud father of one child.

He has been selling shoes for five years. He gets additional income from his rental houses. He would like 40,000 Kenyan Shillings to buy stocks of fashionable shoes.

In the next five years he wants to expand his business into wholesale. He is grateful to Faulu Kenya for educating him financially.

loans.use: to buy stocks of fashionable shoes

loans.name: Mwanatumu

texts.en:
Mwanatumu is a married woman with one child who attends school. She lives in a rental house that has electricity but not piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

For the past two years she has operated a clothes-selling business, selling door-to-door to her neighbours and passersby. Her major challenge is competition from other clothes-sellers in the market. She dreams of opening a clothes shop in the future.

With the KES 20,000 loan she wants to purchase bundles of clothes for sale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase bundles of clothes for sale

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To complete paying for his taxi

loans.name: Gayane

texts.en: Gayane is from the village of Akhouryan in the Shirak region of Armenia.  She is a widow with three chidren – a twenty-three-year-old daughter and two sons (sixteen and twenty-six).  Gayane has a high school education and has been a sole entrepreneur engaged in farming for the past twenty-five years.  She considers herself a hard-working honest person.  Gayane would like a loan to purchase potato seeds and feed.  This investment should increase Gayane’s family income by ten percent.  With some of the proceeds from the investment Gayane will be saving some money to renovate the family home.  She is proud of living in Akhouryan and the ability to maintain her family.

loans.use: to purchase potato seeds and feed

loans.name: Morice

texts.en:
Morice is a hard-working businessman. He is married and is blessed with four children.

For five years he has been selling second-hand clothes. He also does welding to supplement his income. 

Thanks to Faulu Kenya, he has been able to access finance to purchase more clothes and has learned methods for managing his business. He hopes to grow his business into a wholesale business. He would like KES 30,000 to buy stocks of second-hand clothes.

loans.use: to buy second-hand clothes for resale

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase bundles of clothes for sale

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase sacks of vegetables for resale

loans.name: Neneh

texts.en:
Neneh is 41 years old and married with five children between 6 months and 18 years old. She runs a provisions store in Goderich near Freetown.

Neneh has been in this business for 20 years and sells milk, soft drink, Ovaltine, toiletries and sugar at her store. Her business is the only source of income she has. She says that the main challenge to her business is price inflation.

She requested this loan through BRAC Sierra Leone to purchase more provisions. Neneh says that the extra income from this loan will help her life improve with the profit she will make.  In the future, she would like to expand her business more.

loans.use: To purchase more soft drinks and toiletries

loans.name: Aminata

texts.en:
Aminata is 42 years old and married with four children between the ages of 12 and 24. She runs a cotton and material store in Waterloo near Freetown.

Aminata has been in this business for seven years and sells cotton and traditional patterned material at her store. Her business is the only source of income she has. She says that the main challenge to her business is price fluctuation.

She requested this loan through BRAC Sierra Leone to purchases more lace, cotton and material. Aminata says that the extra income from this loan will help her educate her children. In the future, she would like to be a supplier to other business partners.

loans.use: To purchase more lace, cotton and material

loans.name: Daniel

texts.en:
Daniel is 31 years old and married with two children ages two and five. He runs a general merchandise store in Waterloo near Freetown.

Daniel has owned this business for seven years and sells clothes and cosmetic creams at his store. His business is the only source of income he has. He says that the main challenge to his business is price inflation.

He requested this loan through BRAC Sierra Leone to purchase more clothes and cosmetic creams. Daniel says that the extra income from this loan will help him improve the standard of living and the health of his family. In the future, he would like to supply stock within the city.

loans.use: To purchases more clothes and cosmetic creams

loans.name: Alfred

texts.en:
Alfred is 42 years old and married with three children between the ages of 6 and 16. He runs a material store in Waterloo near Freetown.

Alfred has been in this business for eight years and sells lace, cotton and material at his store. His business is the only source of income he has. He says that the main challenge to his business is rapid inflation.

He requested this loan through BRAC Sierra Leone to purchase more lace and materials. Alfred says that the extra income from this loan will help him improve the health of his family. In the future, he would like to be a supplier of material.

loans.use: To purchase more lace and materials

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy a motorbike

loans.name: Patung 2 Group

texts.en:
Manti, the group leader of Patung 2, is 32 years old. She is married and has 4 children. She has sold sculptures around the traditional market since 2009. The other group members, Rohana, Anita and Umi also sell sculptures, which is why their group name is Patung(sculpture) 2.

Manti's problem is that she doesn't have her own kiosk; that's why she needs to go around the traditional market every day. She hopes she can save her money and open her own kiosk in a strategic place to invite more buyers.

Now, her daily income is used to fulfill the family's daily need and also to pay her children's school fees.

loans.use: to buy sculptures

loans.name: Furaha

texts.en:
Furaha is a married woman with two children. One of the children attends school and the other one is still too young for school. She lives in a rental house that has electricity but not piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

For the past year, she has operated a clothes selling business. She sells from door to door to her neighbors and passersby. She faces a major challenge of competition in her business. Furaha dreams of establishing a boutique shop in the future.

With the Kshs 20,000, she wants to purchase bundles of clothes to sell. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: To purchase bundles of clothes to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase additional wholesale products to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase more food items to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more freezers

loans.name: Mubariz

texts.en:
Mubariz is married and has two children. His family lives in Bilasuvar, Internally Displaced Settlement. 

Mubariz has a grocery store and sells food items. His business boasts fresh groceries, reasonable prices, flexible and quality client service, and uniqueness and variety of merchandise. Mubariz works hard to develop his business and make his business profitable. 

He started with working capital of 200 USD which he took from AqroInvest CU, and another two loans also helped him to reach goals and bring him to his current success. Mubariz is requesting a loan of 1300 AZN to reconstruct and modernize his grocery store, to increase turnover capital and to purchase an assortment of goods for retail sale. Mubariz is planning to use the generated profit to remodel his old house. 

Mubariz is a conscientious and focused manager of his resources and always plans his time and finances. In all his business dealings, he is guided by a sense of trust and goodwill towards others, especially to AqroInvest CU. We believe these qualities will help him repay his loan without any delinquencies.

loans.use: to modernize his grocery store and to purchase more food merchandise for retail sale

loans.name: Naseem's Group

texts.en:
Naseem is a 51-year-old married woman with two children: a son and a daughter. Her son got his education to the 8th standard and now works as a salesman. Her daughter got her education to the 5th standard and learned the skill of embroidery from Naseem. Naseem is a housewife, managing her household work by staying at home. In her spare time, she also does sewing for neighbors and makes some money to manage the household expenses. Her husband is a carpenter by profession and makes furniture on order. He is very skillful in his work and makes beautiful furniture designs for his clients. 

Naseem has applied for a loan from Kiva's partner, Asasah, for her son’s business. With the loan, her son will buy edible items such as Nimko, biscuits and chips, etc., to be able to meet his clients' orders and earn profit.
