Estrelita is from Cabiriuan Gonzaga, Cagayan.  She has run a general store for five years, earning the average net income of PHP3,000 each month.  In the store, Estrelita even sells fish. Her business income is invested in livestock raising and some is saved for future use. 

She is 42 years old and is married to a farmer. As of this moment, Estrelita has no child, but is praying for one soon. In the future, Estrelita dreams of better living standards.  She is requesting a loan amount of PHP8,000 to purchase groceries, such as soft drinks.

loans.use: to purchase groceries, such soft drinks

loans.name: Sisilia

texts.en:
Sisilia is a married woman with two children, both of whom attend school. She lives in a rental house that has electricity but not piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

For two years, she has operated a charcoal business, selling at the market to her neighbors and passersby. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business. Sisilia dreams of expanding her business in the future.

With the Kshs 20,000, she wants to purchase sacks of charcoal for sale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase sacks of charcoal for sale.

loans.name: Gulzat

texts.en:
Gulzat is 29 years old and single. She has two children. In 2003, in order to find means of subsistence for her children, Gulzat decided to start up her own business in hairdressing. She started with the initial capital of 10,000 KGS and managed to earn about 15,000 KGS in a month. She rented a room with five workstations in the center of Djalal-Abad town and could make her salon known by a creative and modern approach to hairdressing.

Gulzat proposes to use this loan of 120,000 KGS to purchase good equipment for her salon in order to attract new customers. With the revenue from the loan, Gulzat plans to further broaden her business and dreams of making it one of the best barber shops in the local area.

Bai-Tushum and Partners uses Kiva funding to target the especially vulnerable population. Bai-Tushum and Partners is one of the leading microfinance institutions in Kyrgyzstan. As a reliable financial partner, Bai-Tushum contributes to the economic development of the Kyrgyz Republic through the delivery of microfinance services in rural and urban areas that lead to increased employment and meet the interests of its clients and investors.

loans.use: to purchase equipment.

loans.name: Asha

texts.en:
Asha is a married woman with five children. Three children attend school, and the other two are grown. She owns a house that neither has electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

For the past 10 years, she has operated a business selling cashew nuts in the market to her neighbors and passersby. Asha faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business. She dreams of expanding her business and becoming a wholesale supplier in the future.

With the 20,000 KES, Asha wants to purchase sacks of cashew nuts to sell. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase sacks of cashew nuts to sell.

loans.name: Mariam

texts.en:
Mariam is a married woman with three children, all of whom attend school. She owns a house that has electricity but not piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is school fees for her children.

She has operated a restaurant business for the past six years. Her potential customers are neighbors and passersby. She faces a major challenge of seasonality and perishability of products in her business. Mariam dreams of incorporating other businesses, like the selling of vegetables, in the future.

With the 20,000 KES, Mariam wants to purchase sacks of beans, maize flour, and rice and to renovate her business premises. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: To purchase sacks of beans, maize flour, and rice and to renovate her business premises.

loans.name: Ouk

texts.en: Ouk, age 39, is an animal feeder. Her husband is an electrician. Their income is 8 USD per day. They have four children, ages 18, 17, 13, and 5. Every month, she has to spend 25 USD on food and 35 USD on other expenses. She would like to request a loan of 500 USD to buy chickens and pigs to sell. She also plans to make cages for the animals. She also wants to repair her house to make it more comfortable, as now it is not in good condition at all. She hopes that she can make a good profit from this career.

loans.use: to buy more chickens and pigs to sell.

loans.name: Amor Y Amistad 3 & 4 Group

texts.en:
Martire is the coordinator of his group Amor y Amistad 3 & 4 (Love and Peace). He makes his home here in a simple structure with his long-term partner and their two children.

Martire is excited to be taking his thirteenth loan with Esperanza, after having successfully repaid his previous loan and having developed his business by expanding his client base and by buying more products. He has had his business for around eight years, starting with the first loan he received from Esperanza, after some neighbors invited him to join the group. He plans to use this loan to invest in his business by purchasing pounds of fish and chicken to sell, as well as coconuts in order to sell their water. He will continue using his business profits to provide a better life for his family by building their house and by providing warm food, clothing, and for other needs.

His group is located in Samana, a lush rugged peninsula with a burgeoning tourism industry, where most of the group members sell their products in their communities and surrounding areas. Martire thanks you for your support in helping them achieve their dreams of being successful in the future.

loans.use: to buy coconut, fish, and chicken.

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth is a married woman with five children, all of whom attend school. She owns a house that has electricity but not piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

Elizabeth has operated a business selling clothes. She sells clothes wholesale to retail clothing sellers in the market. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business. She dreams of establishing a general store in the future.

With the 20,000 KES, she wants to pay school fees for her two children. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to pay school fees for her two children.

loans.name: Irene

texts.en:
Irene is a married woman with one child who attends school. She lives at a rental house that has electricity but not piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

For the past five years, Irene has operated a tailoring business, offering tailoring services to her neighbors. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business. Her dream is to expand her business in the future.

With the 20,000 KES, she wants to purchase cloth materials for her tailoring business. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: To purchase cloth materials for her tailoring business.

loans.name: Fatuma

texts.en:
Fatuma is a married woman with three children, all of whom attend school. She owns a house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is school fees.

For the past three years, she has owned rental houses whereby tenants are her potential customers. Fatuma faces a major challenge of competition from other real estate owners in her business. She dreams of expanding her business in the future.

With the 20,000 KES, she wants to renovate her rental house by purchasing cement, sand, and paints. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: To renovate her rental property by purchasing cement, sand, and paints.

loans.name: Meas

texts.en: Mrs. Meas, 51, is a rice farmer residing in the Prey Chor district of Kompong Cham Province. She raises pigs in a pigpen behind her house and sells them to a slaughterer in four-month cycles. She also plants a rice crop for her annual business. Her husband always assists her in the farming business. Mrs. Meas is looking for a loan as capital to support her farming business. She will use it to buy more piglets and to purchase rice seed for planting. Mrs. Meas has three children; two attend school and one is married and lives in another house.

loans.use: to buy more piglets and rice seed

loans.name: Dy

texts.en: Dy, age 31, is a farmer. Her husband is a construction worker, and he sells cow collars. Their income is 10 USD per day. They have two children, ages 12 and 6. Every month, Dy has to spend 70 USD on food, 5 USD on electricity, 10 USD on school fees, 40 USD on transportation, and 20 USD on other expenses. She would like to request a loan of 800 USD to buy more ropes to twist into cow collars to sell. She wants to sell more cow collars to get more income and to extend that business with her husband. With her profit, she would like to send both of her children to study until they finish university.

loans.use: to buy more ropes to twist into cow collars to sell.

loans.name: Thol

texts.en: Thol, age 31, is a weaver. Her husband is a motor taxi driver (a motorbike with a cart attached). Their income is 11 USD per day. They have two children, ages 4 and 2. Every month, Thol has to spend 75 USD on food, 5 USD on electricity, 50 USD on transportation, and 40 USD on other expenses. She would like to request a loan of 800 USD to buy a new motorbike with a cart attached for her husband to earn money. The old motorbike is broken and needs to be fixed a lot. If her husband can make a good profit, she wants to feed chickens and pigs at home, and she will send all of her children to study until they finish university.

loans.use: To buy a Tok Tok (a motorbike with a cart attached).

loans.name: Zainab

texts.en:
Zainab is a single woman who lives at a rental house that has electricity but not piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is rent bills.

For the past three years, she has operated  a tailoring business, selling at the market and from door to door to her neighbours and passersby. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business. She dreams of owning a fresh water selling business in the future.

With the Kshs 40,000 she wants to start another business of water distribution, purchase pipes and an electric meter, to install plumbing, and to purchase a license for her business. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: To purchase pipes and an electric meter, to install plumbing, and to purchase a license for her business.

loans.name: Sopheap

texts.en:
Sopheap, a 34-year-old fruit seller, and her husband, a sugar cane seller, earn a combined daily income of $18. They have two children, one a 14-year-old worker, and the other a 6-year-old student. Sopheap's monthly expenses consist of $83 for food, $15 for electricity, $50 for rent, $15 for school fees, $45 for transportation and $50 for other expenses.

She is now requesting a loan of $1200 to buy more fruit to sell, her ultimate goal being to save enough money to buy a small store and to send her child to university to study law.

loans.use: to buy more fruit to sell.

loans.name: Harriet

texts.en:
Harriet is a widow with one child in school. She lives at a rental house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are rent bills and food for the family.

For the past nine years, Harriet has operated a beauty salon business. Her potential customers are neighbors and passersby. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business. She dreams of owning a well-furnished beauty salon.

With the 40,000 KES, she wants to furnish her house and to purchase six windows, three doors, cement, and sand. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: To furnish her house and to purchase six windows, three doors, cement, and sand.

loans.name: Skeeter

texts.en:
Skeeter is a married woman with four children, all of whom attend school. She lives in a rental house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

For the past three years, she has operated a food vending business, selling to her neighbors and passersby. She faces a major challenge of high cost of transportation and seasonality in her business. She dreams of establishing a café business in the future.

With the 40,000 KES, she wants to build a business structure by purchasing timber and iron sheets and by paying for labor. She decided to join Yehu to improve her living standards.

loans.use: to build a business structure by purchasing timber and iron sheets and by paying for labor.

loans.name: Fatuma

texts.en:
For the past eight years, Fatuma has been selling juice from her home to her neighbours and passersby. In addition, she owns real estate houses which contributes another source of income. She faces the major challenge of seasonality in her business. She dreams of owning a cloth selling shop in the future.

Fatuma is a married woman with two children, both of whom attend school. She owns a house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is school fees. 

With this loan of 60,000 Kenyan shillings, she wants to repair her ceiling board, purchase plywood and timber, and pay for labor. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to repair her ceiling board, purchase plywood and timber, and pay for labor.

loans.name: Chum

texts.en: Mrs. Chum lives in the Prey Chor district of Kompong Cham Province. She grows rice crops at least twice a year, following the rainy and dry seasons. Mrs. Chum’s husband works in construction to earn an income and share financial responsibilities with her. They are blessed with three single children who still attend the local school and rely on their parents' income. Mrs. Chum is asking for a $600 loan to purchase additional wooden planks to build her new house.

loans.use: to purchase additional wooden planks to build her new house.

loans.name: Leonardo

texts.en:
Leonardo is a 50-year-old married man living in Pinopoc Alcala, Cagayan. He has three school-aged children. Leonardo's spouse works as a housekeeper.

Leonardo has been in the business of hog raising for three years. As of now, all his hogs are disposed of and he earned PHP 5,000. He is requesting a loan as additional capital to purchase new pigs to raise and buy the necessary feed for maintenance. 

In the future, Leonardo would like to educate all his children by sending them to school and earn additional income to save for future emergencies.

loans.use: to purchase pigs and feed

loans.name: Zohirchon

texts.ru: Зохирчон проживает в городе Кургантюбе. Ему 29 лет. Он женат. У него двое детей. Его жена домохозяйка. Сам Зохирчон занимается растениеводством и одновременно животноводством. Он в основном выращивает овощи и сеет арбуз. Кроме того он откармливает и продает скот. То есть он разводит скот в дальнейшем для продажи. Этим видом деятельности он занимается 5 лет. Кредит берет для покупки 2 телят.
texts.en: Zohirchon lives in the city of Qurgan-Tube.  He is 29 years old, married and has two children.  His wife is a homemaker.  Zohirchon is involved in horticulture and also animal husbandry.  He primarily grows vegetables and plants watermelons.  Besides this, he fattens up and sells livestock or rather he breeds livestock for subsequent sale.  He has been involved in this type of business for five years and is requesting this loan for the purchase of two calves.

loans.use: to purchase two calves

loans.name: Fatuma

texts.en:
Fatuma is a divorced woman with three children, all of whom are adults. She owns a house that has electricity but not piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

For the past five years, she has operated a food vending business, selling from door to door to her neighbors and passersby. Fatuma faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business. She dreams of owning a café in the future.

With the KSHS 30,000, she wants to purchase utensils and 100 plates for her food vending business. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to improve her living standard.

loans.use: To purchase utensils and plates for her food vending business.

loans.name: Moun

texts.en: There are numerous Cambodians who make a living as domestic rice cultivators; one of them is Mrs. Moun who has been working in this sector since 2008. She and her husband grow different kinds of crops and fruit on their own farmland that they inherited from their grandparents. From this business they can generate an income of around 11 USD per day. This polite couple has three single children who are students. This rainy season, the family wants to plant potatoes, but they don’t have money to grow them. Because of this issue, Mrs. Moun needs a loan from Kiva in order to plant potatoes.

loans.use: to plant potatoes

loans.name: Fatuma

texts.en:
Fatuma is a married woman with seven children. Five of the children attend school and two are still too young for school. She lives at a rental house that has electricity but no piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

For the past three months, she has operated a perfume selling business and a business selling clothes, which contributes to her other source of income. She faces a major challenge of the high cost of transportation in her business. She dreams of owning a cosmetics shop in the future.

With the KSHS 20,000, she wants to purchase body sprays and ladies dresses to sell. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: To purchase body sprays and ladies dresses to sell

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en:
Agnes is age 50 and a married mother of five children who are all adults. She has a mixed farm in Kisii town, in western Kenya that produces maize, coffee, vegetables and nappier grass, which are all sold to the local market. She has been in the farming business for over 30 years and depends on the income from her farm to cater to the needs of her family.

Agnes has made a third loan request through Juhudi Kilimo of 80,000 KES to purchase a motorcycle. She says that this motorcycle will enable her to transport her farm produce to the market and access other local markets. She plans to use the extra income from this project to pay school fees for her youngest child who is currently attending school.

Her major challenges in this business have been unpredictable weather conditions, which affects her production and lack of enough capital for expansion. She plans to purchase a van and a posho mill in the near future.

loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle for transporting her farm produce to the market.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase beans, wheat flour, cooking fat oil and charcoal.

loans.name: Francisca

texts.en:
This is Francisca, 52, a resident of Pasay, Philippines. She is married to Manolo, a Public Councilor. She has four children who all now have their own families. She, together with her husband, manages their own household while operating the business.

Francisca operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store, which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, a PHP 5-worth of cooking oil, or an egg. Francisca earns by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece. Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of PHP 500 in sales every day.

To help her continue operating her business, she is requesting a PHP 37,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Francisca hopes to be able to expand soon. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for grocery products and inventory items for her variety store

loans.name: Joel

texts.en:
Joel is 36 years of age and married with five school-aged children. He is a farmer working in the Philippines. Joel's wife is a housekeeper. Joel is asking for a loan to purchase inputs needed in their field such as fertilizers like manure and hybrid seeds of rice. 

He will also use the loan to pay for the land preparation for his farm. In the future, Joel hopes that his business will earn a high enough income from the yields to continue sending his children in school and finish their education.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers such as manure and hybrid seeds of rice.

loans.name: Cristeta

texts.en: Cristeta, 56 years of age, is widowed and a mother of four children. She's engaged in food vending, particularly rice cake vending. She's been doing this business for almost 32 years. Her net income is 5,000 PHP a month. She's asking a loan for 12,000 PHP to purchase additional raw ingredients for her business. She would like to continue receiving loans to aid the growth of her business and generate profits to invest in the future.

loans.use: To purchase additional raw ingredients

loans.name: Zawadi

texts.en:
Zawadi is a married woman with eight children. Seven of the children attend school and one is still young for school. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

For the past two years, she has operated a business selling coconuts from home to her neighbors and passersby. In addition, she also sells groundnuts, which contributes to her other source of living. Zawadi faces the major challenge of seasonality in her business. She dreams of expanding her business in the future.

With the KSHS 10,000, she wants to pay school fees for her child. She decided to join Yehu to access loans and expand her business.

loans.use: To pay school fees for her child.

loans.name: Relin

texts.en:
Relin is 29 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is widowed with three children. 

Relin has a retail shop that sells canned goods, biscuits & breads. She has had this business for one year. She requested a loan for PHP 5,000 to buy snacks, beverages & breads.

Relin is a new member of HSPFI.  In the future, Relin hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy snacks, beverages & breads

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow.

loans.name: Samuel

texts.en: Samuel is 55 years old and married with six adult-aged children. Samuel's wife works as a fulltime housewife. Samuel is a farmer working in the Philippines. Samuel has been growing rice for 10 years. He is asking for a loan to buy seeds and fertilizer for the farm. In the future, Samuel hopes that his farming business improves so that he can sustain the needs of his family.

loans.use: to buy seeds and fertilizer

loans.name: Armida

texts.en:
Armida is 39 years old and lives in the Philippines.  She is married with 4 children. 
Armida is providing motorcycle or habal-habal services with her husband as the driver. She has had this business for 7 years. 

She requested a loan for PHP 5,000 to buy tools and to pay for the utilities needed for the maintenance of the service.
Armida is a new member of HSPFI.  In the future, Armida hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy tools and to pay for the utilities needed for the maintenance of the service

loans.name: Sangimurod

texts.ru: Сангимурод проживает в городе Кургантюбе. Возраст, 47 лет. Женат. Имеет троих детей. Его сын находится в Российской Федерации. Сам Сангимурод зарабатывает путем разведения крупнорогатого скота. Он разводит скот у себя дома. Этим видом деятельности занимается более 15 лет. Кредит берет для закупа крупнорогатого скота.
texts.en: Sangimurod lives in the city of Qurgan-Tube.  He is 47 years old, married and has three children.  His son is currently in the Russian Federation.  Sangimurod earns a living by breeding cattle.  He breeds livestock at home and has been involved in this type of business for over 15 years.  He is requesting this loan for the purchase of cattle.

loans.use: to purchase cattle

loans.name: Eduardo

texts.en:
Eduardo is 45 years old.  He is married with 4 adult aged children.  Eduardo's wife works as a full time house wife.  He wanted a progressive living for his family and so he is working hard for it through farming.

Eduardo is a farmer working in the Philippines.  Eduardo grows rice and has been doing it for 10 years.  Eduardo is asking a loan to buy seed and fertilizer to maintain his farm.  In the future, he hopes that his farming business will expand so that he can sustain the needs of his family.

loans.use: to buy seed and fertilizer to maintain his farm.

loans.name: Arnel

texts.en:
Arnel is a married man from the town of Sto. Nino South Cotabato.  He has three children.  His eldest child is 11 while his youngest is 9.  He is a farmer and has been tilling their rice farm for 8 years now.

His average income from his business is PHP 12,000 per month.  He utilizes his income to provide his family with their basic needs.  Receiving a loan would help him buy farm supplies like fertilizers and seeds.

In the future, Arnel hopes to manage a bigger farm and be able to send all of his children to college.

loans.use: to buy farm supplies like fertilizer and seeds

loans.name: Vilma

texts.en:
This is Vilma, age 38, a resident of Pasay, Philippines.  She is married to Hacer, a Supervisor.  She has four children.  She, together with her husband, manages their own household while operating the business.

Vilma operates a variety store. In the Philippines.  A variety store is basically a small convenience store, which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood.  It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, a PHP 5 worth of cooking oil, or an egg.  Vilma earns it by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece.  She also sells personal products via direct selling.  Her store is adjacent to her house.  Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of PHP 900 in sales every day.

To help her continue the operations of her business, she is requesting a PHP 45,000 loan.  She will be utilizing the loan to buy groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory.  She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Vilma hopes to be able to expand her store to other communities.  She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for grocery products and inventory items needed in her variety store

loans.name: Mzomba

texts.en:
Mzomba is a widowed woman with nine children, three of whom attend school while six graduated from school.  She owns a house that neither has electricity nor piped water.  Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

For the past three years, she has operated a vegetables sale business from home that sells to her neighbours and passersby. In addition she also operates a food stall selling business.  She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business.  She dreams of expanding her business in the future.

With the KES 40,000 she wants to purchase maize flour and build a permanent vegetable stall.  She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: To purchase maize flour, wheat flour and build a permanent vegetable stall.

loans.name: Jinkie

texts.en: Jinkie, a 22-year-old married mother of three children in the Philippines, has been providing motorcycle or habal-habal services for eight years. A new member of HSPFI, she is requesting a loan for PHP 5,000 to buy tools and pay for the cost of utilities incurred in providing services. In the future, Jinkie hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy tools and pay for the cost of utilities in providing services.

loans.name: Maria

texts.en: Maria, a 59-year-old widow  with seven children, lives in the Philippines where she has been operating a retail shop that sells canned goods, snacks, biscuits, breads and  noodles for the past 20 years. A member of HSPFI since 2010, she is requesting a loan for PHP 8,000 to buy snacks, beverages and canned goods. In the future, Maria hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy snacks, beverages and canned goods.

loans.name: Rehema

texts.en:
Rehema, a married mother of two boys and three girls, lives in a rental house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food, clothing and rent bills.

For the past four years, Rehema has been selling fish from home to her neighbors and passersby. She faces the major challenge of competition from other fish sellers in the market, and she dreams of establishing a retail outlet in the future.

With the Kshs 20,000 loan, Rehema will purchase bundles of fish and a frying pan in which to cook them. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase bundles of fish and a frying pan.

loans.name: Consuelo

texts.en: Consuelo, a 59-year-old mother of three children, is married to a farmer. A rice-grower for 25 years in Sto. Niño, South Cotabato, she works hard to support her family.  Consuelo will use the loan to purchase seeds and fertilizers, and in the future she hopes to improve her family's living conditions.

loans.use: to purchase seeds and fertilizers.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase and insure a dairy cow.

loans.name: Muratbek

texts.ru:
Муратбеку 40 лет, женат и воспитывает четыре дочки, самой старшей из которых - 11 лет.
Муратбек родился в простой семье чабана. Он был самым старшим из братьев, у него было два младших брата, и поэтому большую часть времени посвящал домашним хлопотам. По окончании школы Муратбека призвали в армию. Отслужив два года, Муратбек  поступает в местное училище, по специальности тракторист механик широкого профиля. Отучившись, он устроился на работу в родном колхозе трактористом. В 1995 году Муратбек женился и в этом же году у них родился первый сын. Первое время Муратбек со своей молодой семьей жил у родителей, пока колхоз не выделил ему участок земли под строительство дома, а также - землю для выращивания сельхозкультур. Муратбек приложил все силы для развития своего бизнеса в полеводстве и смог на доходы от урожая закупить скот. Со временем, вкладывая прибыль от перепродажи откормленного скота, он выстроил небольшой дом со всеми необходимыми для бизнеса  хозпостройками. 
В 1998 году с распадом колхоза Муратбек решил взять в аренду сельхозтехнику и предоставлять услуги населению в обработке земли. Семья Муратбека потихоньку растет, растут и потребности. В связи с этим,  он решил получить кредит в сумме 100,000 сом (KGS) и купить грузовую автомашину для предоставления услуг населению по грузоперевозкам. 
На данный момент благодаря упорству и трудолюбию Муратбека, в хозяйстве у него насчитываются 3 дойных коровы, 5 бычков и 4 телочки. В планах у Муратбека приобретение собственного трактора, а также увеличение поголовья скота. 
ЗАО МФК "Бай-Тушум и Партнеры" предоставляет кредиты по линии Кива для социально-уязвимых слоев населения. ЗАО МФК "Бай-Тушум и Партнеры" является одной из лидирующих Микрофинансовых организаций Кыргызстана. "Бай-Тушум и Партнеры" – это надежный финансовый партнер, осуществляющий вклад в развитие экономики Кыргызской Республики путем предоставления доступных микрофинансовых услуг в сельской местности и городах, способствующих созданию рабочих мест и отвечающий интересам своих клиентов и инвесторов.
texts.en: Muratbek is 40 years old.  He is married and is raising four daughters, the oldest out of whom is 11 years old.  Muratbek was born in a simple family of a shepherd.  He was the oldest out of his brothers and had two younger brothers, which is why he spent a majority of his time doing household work.  Upon finishing school, Muratbek was drafted into the army.  Having served two years, Muratbek attended a local college and learned the profession of a wide-scope tractor operator and mechanic.  After finishing college, he got a job as a tractor operator at his native collective farm.  Muratbek got married in 1995 and had his first son this same year.  At first, Muratbek and his young family lived with parents up until the collective farm allocated a plot of land to build a house and land to grow agricultural products.  Muratbek put all of his efforts toward developing his farming business and was able to use his profit from the harvest to buy livestock.  Over time, Muratbek invested profits from reselling grown livestock into building a small house with all of the storage sheds necessary for the business.  When the collective farm dissolved in 1998, Muratbek decided to lease farm equipment and offer land treatment services to the public.  Muratbek's family is slowly growing, with their needs growing as well.  To better meet their growing needs, Muratbek decided to obtain a loan in the sum of 100,000 som (KGS) and buy a heavy-duty truck in order to offer transportation services to the public.  Currently, thanks to his persistence and hard work, Muratbek has three dairy cows, five bulls and four heifers.  Muratbek plans to buy his own tractor and increase the quantity of livestock.

loans.use: to purchase a truck

loans.name: Juliah

texts.en:
Juliah, a married mother of five grown children, has been practicing mixed farming for the last 12 years in her hometown in western Kenya. Employing four farmhands, her farm produces maize and beans which are all sold locally. She is also a teacher at a local school.

Juliah has requested a loan through Juhudi Kilimo of 45,000 Kes to purchase and insure a dairy cow. The extra income from the sale of milk will enable her to expand her farming activities and improve her family's livelihood.

Juliah's biggest challenges have been diseases and inadequate amounts of animal feeds, both of which affect her production. She plans to acquire two more dairy cows and purchase land upon which to build rental houses in the next five years.

loans.use: to purchase and insure a dairy cow.

loans.name: Visaminda

texts.en:
Visaminda is 46 years old and lives in Canubay, Oroquieta City. She is married with 3 children.

To earn a living, Visaminda has a business selling different kinds of fish. She earns about 4,000 PHP each month doing this type of work. Visaminda has requested a loan to purchase more fish to sell.

Visaminda has been a member of PMPC for 2 years.

loans.use: to purchase more fish to sell

loans.name: Rosalie

texts.en:
Rosalie is 27 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with 3 children.

Rosalie has a shop that sells snacks, beverages and canned goods. She has had this business for 5 years. She requested a loan of 8,000 PHP to buy snacks, canned goods and beverages.

Rosalie has been a member of HSPFI since 2010. In the future, Rosalie hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy snacks, canned goods and beverages

loans.name: Aurea

texts.en:
This is Aurea, 50, a resident of Pasay, Philippines. She is married to Samson, a supervisor. She has three children; the oldest is in high school, while the other two are in grade school.  She, together with her husband, manages their own household while operating the business.

Aurea operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, a 5 PHP-worth of cooking oil, or an egg. Aurea earns by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece. Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of 500 PHP in sales every day.

To help her continue the operation of her business, she is requesting a 17,000 PHP loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Aurea hopes to be able to expand soon. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week, and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for grocery products and inventory items needed in her variety store

loans.name: Flermina

texts.en:
Flermina is a married woman with four children, all of whom attend school. She lives in a rental house that has electricity but not piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food, clothing and rent bills.

For the past 10 years, she has operated a beauty salon business. Her potential customers are neighbours and passersby. In addition, she also operates a dressmaking school, which contributes to her other source of income. She faces a major challenge of competition from other beauty salon operators. She dreams of expanding her business in the future.

With the 20,000 KES, she wants to purchase a blow dryer for her beauty salon business. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase a blow dryer for her beauty salon business

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth is a married woman with four girls: three attend school while one is still too young for school. She lives in a rental house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are rent bills and school fees.

For the past eight years, she has operated a tailoring business, selling from home to her neighbours and passersby. She faces a major challenge of competition from other tailor operators. She dreams of owning a retail shop in the future.

With the 20,000 KES, she wants to purchase cloth materials and a machine. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase cloth materials and a machine

loans.name: Bathsebah

texts.en:
Bathsebah, a 34-year-old married mother of three children, all attending school, has a mixed farm in the town of Kisii that produces maize, beans, nappier grass and vegetables, all of which she sells locally. She earns additional income from her rental houses in the same town.

Bathsebah has made a loan request of 45,000 Kes through Kiva partner Juhudi Kilimo to purchase and insure a dairy cow. She says that this loan will enable her to acquire a quality dairy cow that will produce enough milk for domestic consumption and sale. The additional profits arising from this loan will be used to build more rental houses that will help increase her income.

Her biggest challenges have been poor market prices for farm produce and fluctuating weather conditions which affect her production.

loans.use: to purchase and insure a dairy cow.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to puchase and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Rosita

texts.en:
This is Rosita, 49, resident of Pasay, Philippines. She is married to Eduardo, a painter. She has three children; the oldest is in high school and the other two are in grade school.  She, together with her husband, manages their own household while operating the business.

Rosita operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store, which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, a Php5-worth of cooking oil, or an egg. Rosita earns by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece. They also operate a passenger motorcycle used in transportation around the community.  Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of Php 1000 in sales every day.

To help her continue the operations of her business, she is requesting a Php 20,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory and for the maintenance of their motorcycle unit. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Rosita hopes to be able to expand soon and dreams to be able to give her children a good and high quality education through all her hard work on her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for grocery products and inventory items needed in her variety store

loans.name: Mohammed

texts.en:
Mohammed is a married man with three children, two boys and one girl. Two of his children attend school while one is still too young for school. He owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. His greatest monthly expenses are food, school fees and clothing.

For the past eleven years, he has operated a cosmetic shop, selling retail to his neighbours and passersby. He faces a major challenge of the high cost of transportation and competition from other cosmetic shop operators in his area of operation. He dreams of purchasing a motorcycle for transport business in the future. 

With the Kshs 40,000 he wants to purchase cosmetics for sale. He decided to join Yehu to access loans to improve his living standard.

loans.use: To purchase cosmetics for sale.

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en:
Evelyn is 48 years old and is a married woman with eight children. The youngest child is six. 

Evelyn is a farmer working in Sto. Niño, South Cotabato. She has been growing rice for 15 years. Evelyn works hard to help provide for her family and sustain her children's education.

This loan will be used to purchase seeds and fertilizers.  In the future, Evelyn hopes for her children to finish college and find jobs.

loans.use: to purchase seeds and fertilizers.

loans.name: Gladys

texts.en:
Gladys is a married woman with four children, all of whom attend school. She lives at a rental house that neither has electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food, clothing and school fees.

For the past three years, she has operated a food stall business, selling at the market to her neighbours and passersby. She faces a major challenge of competition from other food stall operators in her business. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business. 

With the Kshs 20,000 she wants to renovate her food stall, purchase cooking fat, sacks of beans and maize flour. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: To renovate her food stall, purchase cooking fat, sacks of beans and maize flour.

loans.name: Nelly

texts.en:
Nelly is a married woman with two children, both of whom attend school. She owns a house that has electricity but not piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food, clothing and school fees.

For the past two years, she has operated a food stall business, selling from home to her neighbours and passersby. She faces a major challenge of competition from other food stall operators in the market. She dreams of expanding her business in the future.

With the Kshs 40,000 she wants to purchase sacks of Irish potatoes, sacks of beans and cooking fat. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: To purchase sacks of Irish potatoes, sacks of beans and cooking fat.

loans.name: Hellen

texts.en:
Hellen is a farmer from Kisii town in western Kenya. She has been in the farming business for 10 years now and employs four farmhands. Her mixed farm produces bananas, maize and nappier grass which are all sold locally. She mainly depends on the income from her farm to cater for the basic needs of her family.

Hellen has made a loan request of 45,000 Kes to purchase and insure a dairy cow. The extra income from the sale of milk will enable her to pay school fees for her four children who are in college. Her major challenges have been poor market prices for farm produce and fluctuating weather patterns which affect her production.

She plans to acquire more dairy cows in the next five years and also build some rental houses.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow.

loans.name: Basiliza

texts.en:
This is Basiliza, 53, a resident of Pasay City, Philippines. She is married to Maximiano, who is also her business partner. She is the mother of their six children, five of whom are already working and are settled down with their own families, while the youngest is currently enrolled in college. By the grace of God, Basiliza has managed to support her youngest child's schooling up to the college level. At this time, she is working hard to continue sending her youngest to college. This is a dream for most Filipino parents like Basiliza, as she herself has been a college undergraduate and believes that a college diploma is the best inheritance parents could leave to their children.

Basiliza operates a retal business. What she basically does is buy general merchandise from wholesalers and sell it piecemeal with a little profit. Products can range from furniture to household appliances, electronic devices, clothing, electronic phone load, and other products of the like. Customers are attracted to buy due to the low selling price and the many options they are offered. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of Php 600 in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a PHP 15,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy more quantities and varieties of products to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Basiliza dreams of being able to give her youngest child a quality education through all her hard work on her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week and draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay micro-finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for additional stock and products needed in her business.

loans.name: Gaudioso

texts.en:
Gaudioso, 56 years old, is a married man from the town of Sto. Nino, South Cotabato. He has two children. He is a farmer and has been tilling their rice farm for 20 years now.

Gaudioso utilizes his income to provide his family with their basic needs. Receiving a loan would help him buy the farm supplies he needs like fertilizers and seeds.

In the future, Gaudioso hopes for his farm to grow. He also hopes to uplift his family's living conditions.

loans.use: to buy farm supplies like fertilizers and seeds.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow.

loans.name: Asha

texts.en:
Asha is a single woman who owns a house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food, electricity, and clothing.

Asha operates a beauty salon business; her potential customers are neighbors and passersby. She faces a major challenge of competition from other beauty salon operators in the area.  Asha dreams of establishing another beauty salon in the future.

With the Kshs 10,000 she wants to purchase cosmetics and hair weaves. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: To purchase cosmetics and hair weaves.

loans.name: Sakina

texts.en:
Sakina is a married woman with four children, all of whom graduated from school. She owns a house that neither has electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family. 

For the past three years, she has operated a poultry business, selling from door to door and from home to her neighbours and passersby. She faces a major challenge of high cost of transportation in her business. Her dream is to establish a cereal shop in the future.

With the Kshs 25,000 she wants to purchase three bags of beans, chicks and poultry feed. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: To purchase three bags of beans, chicks and poultry feed.
